description: Glycogen storage disease type II or Pompe disease is a rare lysosomal storage disorder which results in the accumulation of glycogen.(8) Glycogen is a carbohydrate (called a polysaccharide) synthesized in humans in order to be used for fuel and structural support or metabolized for energy.(1) Glycogen is stored almost entirely in the liver and the muscles and is the primary source of stored energy for muscle activity during exercise.(1) In Pompe disease, there is a deficiency of the acid alpha-1,4-glucosidase,  an enzyme that breaks down glycogen in lysosomes (the part of a cell that holds enzymes).(1)As a result of the body’s inability to breakdown the glycogen it accumulates in the muscles, resulting in progressive weakness of skeletal and respiratory muscles; other organs also are affected, thus warranting classification of the disease as a multisystem disorder.(7)Late-onset  Pompe disease (LOPD) is characterized by onset between 12 months and adulthood,whereas infantile Pompe (IOPD) is characterized by onset before 12months.(7)(For detailed information on infantile Pompe disease, see Clinical Review…Glycogen Storage Disease Type II (Infantile Pompe Disease)  ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T709205.).The following is a list of organ involvement and clinical manifestations in LOPD(7):
Skeletal muscles –Fatigue –Axial and proximal weakness (> lower limbs) –Scapular winging –Exercise intolerance
Cognitive and emotion –Mild cognitive impairment –Executive functions impairment –Anxiety/depression

ICD-10 codes.R13.19: other dysphagia (ICD codes are provided for the reader’s reference, not for billing purposes)

reimbursement: Reimbursement for assessment and therapy will depend on insurance contract coverage

Medicaid is a joint state-federal  entitlement program in the United States that provides health coverage to low-income Americans.(2) Medicaid offers many benefits for home and community services for patients with long-term  care needs, including individuals living with Pompe disease.(2) Eligibility for Medicaid varies by state, but in every case it is a means-tested  entitlement program(2) Presentation/signs and symptoms: Dysphagia refers to difficulty in any of the stages of swallowing: oral, pharyngeal, and/or esophageal.(41)Briefly, the oral phase includes sucking, chewing, and transporting the bolus into the pharynx. The pharyngeal phase is defined by initiation of the swallow response, pharyngeal clearance, and airway closure to prevent aspiration (food or liquid entering the airway) or choking.(13)Lastly, the esophageal phase consists of the opening of the upper esophageal sphincter and transit of the bolus down the esophagus via peristaltic motion to the stomach.(4,41)Patients with LOPD may have varying degrees of feeding-swallowing  difficulties. They may struggle with both the oral and pharyngeal phases of the swallow,with consequences ranging fromminor oral phase impairment such as oral residue to more significant impairment such as penetration/aspiration.(11)Bulbar muscle involvement resulting in facial hypotonia, tongue weakness, poor lingualROM, and weak pharyngeal muscles all contribute to dysphagia in patients with LOPD(2,3,11)  Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
presentation signs and symptoms: Dysphagia refers to difficulty in any of the stages of swallowing  oral, pharyngeal, and/or esophageal.(41)Briefly, the oral phase includes sucking, chewing, and transporting the bolus into the pharynx. The pharyngeal phase is defined by initiation of the swallow response, pharyngeal clearance, and airway closure to prevent aspiration (food or liquid entering the airway) or choking.(13)Lastly, the esophageal phase consists of the opening of the upper esophageal sphincter and transit of the bolus down the esophagus via peristaltic motion to the stomach.(4,41)Patients with LOPD may have varying degrees of feeding-swallowing  difficulties. They may struggle with both the oral and pharyngeal phases of the swallow,with consequences ranging fromminor oral phase impairment such as oral residue to more significant impairment such as penetration/aspiration.(11)Bulbar muscle involvement resulting in facial hypotonia, tongue weakness, poor lingualROM, and weak pharyngeal muscles all contribute to dysphagia in patients with LOPD(2,3,11)  Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors

pathogenesis: LOPD is inherited; inheritance is autosomal recessive (meaning that it occurs if the person inherits two copies of anabnormal gene, one from each parent)(7,10)
Onset of LOPD can occur any time after the age of 12 months through adulthood(2,3,10)
Patients with Pompe disease have an accumulation of glycogen in the tissues of the body (mainly within the muscles)(7,9,10)

The disease is progressive and functional impairments increase over time(9,10)–Although the disease is progressive, the progression of LOPD is slower than that of IOPD and the overall phenotype isless severe. In LOPD, the heart is typically not affected(3,7)
risk factors: Individuals who are carriers of a GAA  gene mutation on chromosome 17(9)

overall contraindications precautions: Speech-language  pathologists (SLPs) are required to have graduate, postgraduate, or continuing education training specifically in pediatric dysphagia assessment and treatment before completing an evaluation and/or commencing treatment(14)

SLP must have demonstrated competency as defined by American Speech-Language-Hearing  Association (ASHA) guidelines prior to completing instrumental swallow evaluation (videofluoroscopic swallowing study [VFSS] or flexible endoscopic evaluation of swallowing [FEES])(23)

Accurate identification of a feeding-swallowing  disorder is critical due to risk for insufficient food/liquid intake, poor weight gain, nutritional deficiencies, respiratory infection/pneumonia, and aspiration and/or penetration of oral intake(13)

Timely assessment of swallowing is critical in order to initiate a treatment program as soon as possible and to ensure that family and caregivers are aware of the risks associated with the feeding and swallowing disorder
SLP should monitor swallowing skills and efficiency due to the progressive nature of the disorder(11)
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions  under Assessment/

contraindications precautions to examina: In LOPD, dysphagia management is often best performed using a team approach given its multisystem impact. Team members may include SLP, nurse, dietician, pediatrician, occupational therapist (OT), physical therapist (PT), gastroenterologist, and neurologist

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Review patient’s medical chart -When was Pompe disease diagnosed in the patient?(7)

course of treatment.medical management: Medical management of Pompe disease includes ERT was first offered in 2006. In a multicenter study of 90 children and adults with LOPD, 60 received ERT and 30 received placebo over the course of 78 weeks. All patients were ambulatory and free ofinvasive ventilation at baseline. Inclusion criteria were the ability to walk at least 40 m and functional vital capacity (FVC) in upright position between 30 and 80% of normal. The alglucosidase alfatreated  patients showed improvements in walking  distance (6minute  walk test) and stabilization of respiratory function. The trial also revealed a great deal ofvariability in the response to treatment, and some patients continued to deteriorate despite therapy. No data on improvement in swallowing dysfunction were reported(9) In a systematic review and meta-analysis  on the benefit of ERT, Dornelles et al. reported that ERT effectively increases the distance achieved in 6MWT, improves the physical component of QOL, and may decrease time on ventilation (TOV) in treated patients. Functional capacity as measured by FVC was not confirmed. The treatment was deemed to be safe in the studied population, with generally mild adverse events only. No data on swallowing function were included(12) A high-protein  diet and medically supervised exercise therapy are often recommended as part of the treatment plan for patients with Pompedisease(1,3,9) The goal is to decrease glycogen accumulation, increase muscle fatty acid utilization, and compensate for the increased amino acid oxidation that has been shown to occur in Pompedisease(2)
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications the physician has prescribed; are they being taken? Has ERT been started?
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed: The diagnosis of LOPD is confirmed with either molecular genetic studies or biochemical analysis of acid maltase activity of a muscle biopsy(7,9,10)
Document the results of any chest X-rays  and/or swallowing assessments that have been completed(1,3)
EKG is usually normal in patients with LOPD(3)
Muscle biopsy shows the presence of vacuoles that stain positively for the presence of glycogen and evidence of destruction of myofibrils(1,3)

Laboratory findings in patients with LOPD include elevated levels of serum creatine kinase (CK), aspartate aminotransferase (AST), and alanine aminotransferase (ALT).(1)CK levels in patients with IOPD are typically much higher than levels in patients with LOPD
Pulmonary function tests show evidence of reduced forced expiratory volume in 1 second (FEV1) and reduced FVC in erect and supine positions(3)
Diagnosis of LOPD is confirmed with dot blood sample (DBS) testing or enzyme assays to test for GAA activity(1,3)
Most patients with Pompe disease produce endogenous GAA protein, which is called cross-reactive  immunologic
material (CRIM) because it is recognized by antiGAA  antibodies on Western blot analysis. A complete lack of GAA is described as CRIM negative(3)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and their impact, if any
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document if patient has had speech, occupational, or physical therapy for this or other conditions and the benefits

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Does the patient exhibit increased swallowing difficulty -with certain textures of foods or liquids? -with solids more than liquids? -in different environments? -as feeding session progresses? -during certain times of day? -if the patient is fatigued? -in certain positions?
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms related to dysphagia; see Presenting signs/symptoms , above
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (A.M., mid-day,  P.M., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings during nightand also excessive sleep during day -Patients with LOPD often experience abnormal breathing patterns that disrupt sleep(1,10) -Patients with LOPD are at increased risk for sleep apnea(1,3)  -Nocturnal noninvasive ventilation is often recommended for patients with LOPD and has been found to improve QOL(1,7)
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms that the patient is experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (e.g., diarrhea, vomiting, cough, lethargy, weight loss, shortness of breath, incontinence)(7)
history of present illness.respiratory status: The diaphragm and auxiliary respiratory muscles of patients with LOPD usually are impaired,which can result in chronic respiratory failure, carbon dioxide retention, and respiratory insufficiency.(1,7)It is important to document the respiratory status of the patient,including use of supplemental oxygen, noninvasiveventilation, or presence of tracheostomy tube -Patients with LOPD may require mechanical ventilation (most often noninvasive) due to risk of respiratory failure(3) -For detailed information on assessment and treatment of dysphagia in patients with tracheostomy tubes in place, seeChildren with Tracheostomy  ; CINAHL Topic ID NumberAdults with Tracheostomy  ; CINAHL Topic ID Number -The diaphragm is most often affected,which contributes to respiratory failure(9) -As a result of dysphagia in LOPD, patients are at risk of developing repeated episodes of respiratory tract infections(8)Document psychosocial status of both the patient and the parent(s)/caregiver(s).(5)Review any available reports from mental health professionals -When working with patients with LOPD, it is important to be aware of the psychosocial status of the patient and caregiver(s)(2,5) -Disease burden can be overwhelming and often strains marriages, friendships, and other relationships(2) -This stress is a natural part of the shared burdens that surround the care of an individual with LOPD. The patient and/or theirfamilies should be referred to a mental health professional for counseling and support services(2,5) -Patients with LOPD can experience anxiety and depression(7) -A QOL questionnaire is appropriate for patients with LOPD and/or parent(s)/caregiver(s)(3) -SF-36v2  Health Survey(3)A QOL assessment that includes patient self-ratings  of QOL with respect to swallowing and eating ability(6)A measure designed to assess the impact that a child’s swallowing difficultyhas on the child and caregivers(38)Document hearing ability; hearing loss is common in patients with LOPD(3,7) -Hearing loss in patients with LOPD is thought to reflect direct involvement of the cochlea, the conductive apparatus, or both(2,7) -Patients with LOPD should have baselineand annual hearing tests performed by an audiologist(7) Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient and/or caregiver about other symptoms he or she is experiencing

Does the patient attend school?  Where does the patient eat? What types/textures of food? What is the patient’s eating schedule? relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Document height and weight as well as the patient’s percentile on standardized growth charts.(2)Individuals with LOPD are typically delayed in motor milestones or have regressed in their motor milestones. Theyare at risk for inadequate calories, minerals, and vitamins,which can cause protein deficiency(8)
relevant tests and measures.speech and language examination: Speech and language skills are sometimes impaired in patients with LOPD, especially if onset is shortly after 12months.(2,7)Flaccid dysarthria can arise as a result of lingual weakness and respiratory involvement.(2,7)Patients who require ventilators or have tracheostomies as well as those demonstrating speech/language delay will benefit from a complete speech-language evaluation to determine appropriate goals and treatment plans. Though rare in LOPD compared to IOPD, alternative and/or augmentative communication (AAC), including signing and the use of assistive technology, such as voice output systems, might be recommended to increase function, compensate for weakness, and/or promote conservation of energy(2) –For detailed information on assessment and treatment of dysarthria, see the series of Clinical Reviews on this topic –For detailed information on assessment for and treatment utilizing AAC, see the series of Clinical Reviews on this topic
relevant tests and measures.oral structure and oral motor function: Examine the structure and the range, rate, coordination, and symmetry of movement of the lips, facial musculature, tongue, pharynx, and larynx –Patients with LOPD often have reduced lingual strength due to bulbar involvement(7,8,9)Clinical swallow evaluation (CSE) a comprehensive feeding-swallowing  evaluation. It provides an overall picture of a child’s feeding abilities, sensorimotor abilities, and risk of aspiration, and is utilized to develop an initial feeding plan.(15) The SLP must be well-versed  in normal oral motor development and feeding function when evaluating infants, children, and adults. With consideration for chronologic age and developmental level, the patient may be observed swallowing different consistencies using a variety of feeding vessels.(15) An SLP can obtain information regarding oral phase skills but minimal information can be reported regarding pharyngeal swallow physiology during a CSE given the inherent limitations of the evaluation. Additionally, given limited data regarding validated clinical signs of aspiration in pediatrics and the high incidence of “silent” aspiration, instrumental assessments often are warranted for children with suspected dysphagia.(17)In adults, a high incidence of silent aspiration has also been reported in patients with bulbar involvement. When assessing patients with LOPD, special attention should be paid to mastication, bolus formation/control, and oral residue due to weakness of oral musculature including jaw and tongue(11)There are several clinical assessment scales and checklists developed to evaluate infants, children, and adults. However, there is no universally accepted assessment tool. Scales, surveys, and checklists that do not include normative data, validation, or guidelines for interpretation should be used with caution. (18) Scales with normative data should be utilized only after careful review of the specific normative findings such as reliability and validity measures.(33,34,35,36)Though not developed specifically for patients with LOPD, the following are commonly utilizedEvaluation of an infant’s ability to suck on a bottle and/or breast. Includes assessment of child’s feeding history, oral motor skills, oral tactile responses, suck-swallow-breathe coordination, general motor control, and general physical state during feeding and swallowing(19) Evaluation of sucking in infants (up to 3 months of age). Aspects of sucking behavior are classified as normal, disorganized, or dysfunctional(20)Rating scale that examines swallowing and voice in children up to 2 years of age. Ratings include duration of the meal, amount of intake, food consistencies, positioning, sucking from a nipple, sipping from a cup, and coordination of suck-swallow-breathe(31)Standardized screening survey that can be used from 2 years of age through adulthood. Assesses BMI, restrictions in food textures and viscosity, dependence in feeding, and need for special utensils or positioning. Provides information on the severity of the swallowing disorder and can be used as an outcome measure(44)A standardized parent report measure designed to assess eating and drinking in children between the ages of 6 months and 7 years(21)A standardized test designed to assess mastication of solids. The scale has pediatric and adult norms with adequate validity and reliability findings(27,28,29)A  10-question  patient self-rating  of their perceived difficulties with swallowing(30)A 10-question  parent report of their child’s feeding-swallowing difficulties with criterion validity, internal consistency, and reliability measures published(32)In-depth  BedsideT709064In-depth  BedsideT709037A VFSS is performed to assess oral-pharyngeal  swallow physiology and airway protection. A VFSS is most often completed in collaboration with a radiologist.(14) Procedure and interpretation guidelines for completing VFSSs in infants and children are described by Arvedson and Lefton-Greif.(37) For adults, guidelinesoriginally developed by JerilynLogeman and more recently modified by Bonnie Martin-Harris  are typically recommended.(37) In children, the assessment must be age-appropriate with regard to positioning, feeding vessels, and viscosity of materials.(14) The patient is presented with a variety of developmentally appropriate liquids and solids mixed with barium while images are recorded. In adults, typically the exam begins with liquids and progresses to thicker viscosities. The SLP describes oral and pharyngeal swallow physiology, assesses airway protection, and determines the effectiveness of any therapeutic strategy/intervention, including viscosity changes.(14) In contrast to the CSE, the VFSS provides critical information on the pharyngeal phase of the swallow and airway protection.(16) Due to the potential harmful effects of ionizing radiation on children, a repeat VFSS should be completed only after careful consideration.(16) With regard to LOPD, it is recommended that a VFSS be included in any gastrointestinal(14,16,37) Labial seal/closure Sucking Tongue-cupping/tongue  tip elevation for bolus formation/control -Mastication -Anterior-posterior  lingual movement for transport -Initiation of the pharyngeal swallow response -Soft palate elevation and retraction -Anterior hyoid excursion (older children/adolescents/adults) -Laryngeal elevation (older children/adolescents/adults) -Epiglottic inversion (toddlers/children/adolescents/adults) -Laryngeal closure -Pharyngeal stripping wave -Tongue base retraction -Pharyngoesophageal segment opening -Esophageal clearanceModified Barium SwallowT709077  –There are limited studiesavailable that report finding of VFSS performed on patientswith LOPD. However, onestudy (case -In a retrospective study that followed LOPD patients over a 10-year  period, 3 of 12 patients had symptoms of oropharyngeal dysphagia. VFSS completed on these three patients found slow anterior-posterior  oral transit, impaired pharyngeal stripping, and post-swallow  pharyngeal residue. One patient demonstrated frequent penetration and occasional aspiration.(11) Additionally, fatigue of jaw muscles resulting in difficultychewing food wasreportedT709077ModifiedT709046For both children and adults, FEES is performed to evaluate the anatomy and physiology of the pharynx and larynx, the patient’s ability to manage secretions, and the patient’s ability to swallow foods and liquids.(14,40) In addition, it can be used to explore a variety of diagnostic interventions such as postures, maneuvers, consistency changes, and flow rate alterations.(36,40) As with the VFSS, age-appropriate  modifications need to be incorporated into the procedure for children. Food may be dyed to enhance visibility. FEES is preferred over VFSS when safety issues related to radiation exposure are present. Due to the invasive nature of the procedure, it is sometimes difficult to obtain accurate representation of a normal swallow in young children; therefore, patient selection is important.(22,39)ASHA in conjunction with the American Board of Swallowing and Swallowing Disorders have published the Dysphagia Competency Verification Tool (DCVT) to assist training SLPs to perform FEES(23)Flexible Endoscopic EvaluationT709038 and  Clinical Review…Dysphagia AssessmentT709141Oximetry is used to evaluate hemoglobin oxygen saturation levels before, during, and after feeding. Most children have an oxygen saturation level of at least 95%. Low saturation levels (below 90%) could indicate some degree of hypoxia. At present, there is mixed evidence on the utility of pulse oximetry as a reliable method of detecting aspiration during clinical feeding evaluation. This tool should be used in conjunction with other types of swallowing measures and results interpreted with caution(42)Cervical auscultation is a portable, noninvasive technique that involves the use of a stethoscope on the lateral side of the thyroid cartilage to detect cervical sounds generated during swallowing and breath sounds pre and post-swallow. relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: Although the natural course of LOPD results in glycogen accumulation in skeletal and respiratory muscle, autopsy studies have also found glycogen accumulation in the brain, brainstem nuclei, and anterior horn cells.(2,7) Cognitive function is usually normal in LOPD; however, it is possible for the patient to have subtle cognitive impairments.(2,7) Refer to testing/reports by neuropsychologist/psychologist, if available, for specific information and recommendations

other: Aspiration is often silent, especially in younger patients. If there is a history of recurrent respiratory infection, a VFSS or FEES is warranted to assess for the presence of aspiration(14,15)

Patients with dysphagia are at risk for aspiration and penetration of oral intake. Inform the patient and family/caregivers of potential aspiration risks and educate about prevention strategies when appropriate(14)
Decisions regarding dysphagia management are best made using a team approach with the involvement of appropriate specialists and family members(41)

Patients with this diagnosis are at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention  strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention  strategies
Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and consult patient’s physician

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Diagnosis/need for treatment: The diagnosis and management of dysphagia are based on the results of a comprehensive assessment that is performed by an SLP in collaboration with the patient’s primary physician and multidisciplinary team. The primary goal of dysphagia therapy is to support safe and adequate nutrition, maximize QOL, rehabilitate the swallow, and determine the need for supplemental nutrition(14,41)
assessment plan of care.rule out: The patient’s medical team will rule out other diseases with similar symptoms, including glycogen storage disease type III(3,9) glycogen storage disease type IV(3,9) glycogen storage disease type V(3,9) limb girdle muscular dystrophy(3,9) Becker/Duchenne muscular dystrophy(3,9) polymyositis(3,9) rheumatoid arthritis(3,9) nemaline myopathy(9) Werdnig-Hoffmanndisease(9) Danondisease(9)
prognosis: Early diagnosis/treatment with ERT can delay some symptoms or slow progression(12)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Refer to an OT, PT, registered dietitian, respiratory therapist, social worker, neurologist/ neuromuscular specialist, otolaryngologist, radiologist, metabolic disease specialist, geneticist, cardiologist, orthopedist, pulmonologist, or gastroenterologist as necessary.(7,9,10) Refer patient and/or caregivers to a psychologist or counselor if signs of depression are present
other considerations: Patients with LOPD should be kept up to date on all immunizations; both the patient and household members should receive the influenza vaccine during influenza season as an infection can be life-threatening  for the patient(2)
Strict handwashing precautions for the patient, household members, school staff, and all healthcare providers should be implemented to prevent infections(2)
treatment summary: Adults -Swallowing exercises: Swallowing exercises can improve the strength and coordination of swallowing in patients with dysphagia(4). Given the progressive nature of LOPD, discuss appropriateness of exercise program before commencing therapy. To date, no specific studies focusing on the efficacy of swallow rehabilitation exercises with the LOPD population have been published -For detailed information on swallowing exercises, see  Clinical Review…Dysphagia: Swallowing Therapy, Facilitative ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T709080 –Feeding tubes (orogastric, nasogastric, gastrostomy, jejunostomy)/enteral feeding: When safe feeding is not possible in patients with LOPD, enteral feeds can be delivered through a catheter passed through the nose (nasogastric), through the mouth (orogastric), or into the stomach (gastrostomy) or small intestine (jejunostomy)(2) -For detailed information on treatment of dysphagia in childhood, see  Clinical Review…Dysphagia in Childhood  ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708938 -For detailed information on treatment of dysphagia in adults, see the series of Clinical Reviews on swallowing therapy . maintenance or prevention: There is no known way to prevent LOPD
Early diagnosis/treatment with ERT can prevent or delay some symptoms(12)
For patients with LOPD, clinical reassessment by the physician as well as a PT and/or OT should occur routinely to monitor for functional changes(3)
Patients with LOPD with dysphagia should be reevaluated on a regular basis to maintain safety of the recommended diet and feeding protocol as the disease progresses(2,7,11)
patient education: It is important that the dysphagia team educate the parents/caregivers on all recommendations, including liquid or food modifications, positioning, adaptive equipment for feeding, feeding choices and methods, the presence of airway invasion (aspiration), and assess their overall understanding of the swallowing problem and the associated risks

The International Pompe Association (IPA) ( http://www.worldpompe.org/ ) is a federation of Pompe disease patient groups worldwide whose goal is to coordinate activities and share experience and knowledge between different groups

The Acid Maltase Deficiency Association (AMDA) ( www.amda-pompe.org ) and the United Pompe Foundation ( http:// www.unitedpompe.com/ ) aim to increase public awareness and knowledge of Pompe disease as well as support research initiatives at universities in the United States
